Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations and Many Particle Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US based participants in the meeting "Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations and Many Particle Systems" to be held at KTH Royal Institute of Technology Stockholm, Sweden, from November 21-25, 2018.

The workshop is devoted to the latest fundamental and transformative trends in nonlinear evolution partial differential equations (PDE) and applications. Two main goals of this conference are to bring together scientists and mathematicians working in PDE and related fields, and to train and mentor younger generation of mathematicians working in nonlinear PDE and applications. The main impact is to establish a closer tie between researchers in Europe and the US and by pushing the limits of current boundaries of knowledge in nonlinear processes described by PDE to the new level.

Additional information about this meeting can be found at the website: https://www.kth.se/en/sci/institutioner/math

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award supported conference activities in the area of partial differential equations (PDE), uniting different branches of the area, namely, methods and approaches in the kinetic equations and wave-type dispersive equations. While scientific advancement and knowledge exchange were the main goals of this award, the educational element and advancement of junior researchers was another big component of this project.

The main conference took place in November 2018 and was titled "Nonlinear phenomena in Stockholm: Kinetic meets Dispersive". It is a part of the series of conferences and workshops titled "Nonlinear phenomena" that not only showcase the latest achivements in the nonlinear PDE but also try to attract the junior researchers and especially from the under-represented minority population in mathematics. Besides disseminating new results in the area, looking at the different branches of PDEs from various angles, unifying methods and approaches, establishing new collaborations, expanding network across the tow oceans, another main accomplishment of the conference was the majority of speakers and participants were female mathematicians. Moreover, this award allowed to bring the US speakers (mostly female mathematicians) and junior researchers (graduate students and postdocs) from the US to the international location to expand their possibilities of networking and gaining and perfecting the skills in the presentations and talks. Furthermore, there were special sessions, panels and discussions for junior mathematicians explaining differences and similarities in the US and European math graduate and post-graduate education as well as the job market in mathematics on both continents.
